awd_titl_txt: II-NEW: Cognitive Sensing Research Infrastructure for Distributed Behavioral Biometrics
awd_abstract_narration:
Behavioral biometrics, such as gait, walking trajectory, and speech rhythm, are advantageous in their tolerance of low sensory resolution, long sensing distance, and poor environmental conditions. Many applications in security and tele-healthcare require tracking and identification of individuals based on their behavioral traits. Conventional approaches typically use video cameras, which could incur high data throughput and computational costs.
This project aims to develop a research infrastructure that enables tracking and identification of individuals? behavioral biometrics through thermal, pressure, photonic, acoustic, fiber-optic, and laser sensors. Besides low cost, those sensors can produce sparse behavioral biometric data that can be analyzed quickly.  To achieve this goal, we will develop: (1) a set of tools for novel sampling geometries, cognitive sensing protocols, biometric feature modeling and distributed information aggregation; (2) a multi-agent architecture for system operation and adaptation that enables heterogeneous sensors to achieve consensus in behavior analysis; and (3) a set of programming and evaluation tools for system integration and improvement.
The developed computing research infrastructure will enable research activities about behavioral biometrics based on low-cost, low-power, distributed platforms with a variety of sensing modalities. The enabled distributed behavioral biometrics intelligence has great potential to cope with the technical challenges in behavioral biometrics caused by long distances and crowded scenes. The developed education materials will benefit a number of computing and engineering courses for the training of highly skilled workforce on surveillance and security monitoring. The outreach programs include summer student training, faculty workshops, and school visits.

por.por_cntn:
Background: Many intelligent environments and secure systems demand stable and reliable behavioral biometrics, identifying individuals and tracking their actions based on their behavioral attributes. For example, at airport, it is of great interest to find out those people with abnormal behavior or to identify specific suspects whose behavioral biometric signatures have been pre-stored in a database. Conventional video camera based computer vision systems have been used for human tracking and identification but with high computational cost and large data throughput. On the other hand, continuing advances in sensors and sensing methodologies, distributed inference / learning, and wireless networking have enabled distributed alternatives in human tracking and identification.

Intellectual Merit: In this project, Instead of just relying on commercial devices, we have built a research infrastructure that emphasizes low-cost, customized hardware design to achieve a highly adaptive, reconfigurable platform. Our Distributed Behavioral Biometrics (DBB) design has two novelties:

(1) Cognitive Sensors for DBB Information Acquisition. This project has developed a systematic platform to achieve accurate biometric tracking and recognition by enhancing cognition capabilities of DBB sensors. Specifically, we have developed DBB sampling geometry design tools and cognitive sensing protocols to enable distributed biometric information acquisition. In order to establish a testbed with heterogeneous DBB sensors, we have developed a uniform interface for both hardware interconnection and biometric feature representation.

(2) Multi-agent Infrastructure Architecture for DBB Operation and Adaptation. In order to enable distributed biometric information processing, we have developed the DBB CRI based on a multi-agent architecture. Each agent is a hardware /software co-operation unit, and is able to perceive and respond to dynamic biometric tracking or recognition scenarios, while interacting with other agents. Multiple agents can communicate with each other to achieve a global consensus on behavioral analysis. To achieve the above multi-agent architecture, we have developed a set of software drivers for communications and coordination among agents. Reconfigurable digital signal processing (DSP) hardware units are built in agents to enhance DBB system adaptation.

Figure 1 shows multiplex sampling structures for thermal, acoustic and photonic sensors, respectively. A multiplex sampling structure allows multiple spatial sampling elements to use one signal channel, which can improve SNR and increase spatial coherence in signals. Figure 2 shows the proposed reconfigurable sensing protocol and programmable signal conditioning circuit. Based on the knowledge of signals generated by the target, other sensing units, and resources, each sensor’s FOV can be changed through a servo and the signal conditioning circuit. The parameters of signal conditions circuits can be adjusted through I2C communication protocol to achieve different amplification gains and filter bandwidths. Figure 3 shows the fabricated programmable signal conditioning circuit.

Broader Impacts:

(1) Publications: Our results have been published in a few high-quality journal papers, which disseminate our outcomes to the community. Here we list a few of our publications:
